docs.title: Fundamentals of Electronics Tutorial
docs.description: This is a practical, hands-on tutorial on electronic circuits that focuses on modern circuit development for connected things. It starts with fundamentals and builds a solid foundation for doing more complex circuits, with a focus on common circuit designs and microcontroller integrations. For most of the tutorial, only basic proficiency in algebra is necessary.

docs.title: PCB Design Tutorial
docs.description: The most effective way to learn PCB design is to actually design and build one. So that's what we'll do. In this multipart tutorial, we're going to design and build a PCB that is a partial version of Clima that includes  BME280 to track temperature, humidity, and barometric pressure, and get its power from a solar power input. In the end, you'll come away with a general grasp of PCB design from start to finish.

docs.title: Get started with Meadow Core-Compute module
docs.description: Getting started with the Meadow Core-Compute module is similar to getting started with a Meadow Feather board, especially if you are working with the Core-Compute Development Kit which offers breakout headers that mimic the Feather headers.

frontMatter.title: Get started with Meadow Core-Compute module
frontMatter.subtitle: To get up and running with Meadow Core-Compute, follow these steps:

docs.title: Get started with Meadow.Linux
docs.description: Meadow.Linux offers an environment for developing Meadow code that can run on Linux distributions where .NET is available, including Raspberry Pi computers and NVIDIA Jetson development boards where you can access general-purpose input/output (GPIO) pins. Developing with Meadow.Linux requires setting up your development machine with some prerequisites. Then, after connecting any external components, you can deploy and run your Meadow application.

frontMatter.title: Get started with Meadow.Linux
frontMatter.subtitle: To get up and running with Meadow.Linux, follow these steps:

docs.title: Get started with Meadow.Windows
docs.description: Meadow.Windows offers an environment for developing Meadow code that can run on Windows, and with an extra add-on can even access general-purpose input/output (GPIO) pins. Developing with Meadow.Windows requires setting up your development machine with some prerequisites. Then, after connecting any external components, you can deploy and run your Meadow application.

frontMatter.title: Get started with Meadow.Windows
frontMatter.subtitle: To get up and running with Meadow.Windows, follow these steps:

docs.title: Getting Started with Meadow.Desktop
docs.description: Meadow.Desktop offers quick-prototyping and high-responsiveness environments for developing Meadow code that can run on Windows and various Linux distributions, including Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 (WSL2). With appropriate hardware, such as certain single-board computers (SBCs) or using add-on hardware like FT232H modules, you can even access general-purpose input/output (GPIO) pins, SPI, and I2C as you would on a Meadow Feather or Core-Compute module.

frontMatter.title: Getting Started with Meadow.Desktop
frontMatter.subtitle: To get up and running with Meadow.Desktop, follow these steps:

docs.title: Meadow Application Lifecycle Events
docs.description: Meadow provides several connection points to respond to important events in the process of launching and running your application, such as initialization, errors, and sleep states.

frontMatter.title: Meadow Application Lifecycle Events
frontMatter.subtitle: Responding to application lifecycle events as the Meadow board triggers them.

docs.title: Meadow Application Sleep
docs.description: Meadow can be put into a power-saving sleep state. In this state, your code stops executing and reduces the power draw to only what is required to recover from being in a sleep state. After resuming from a sleep state, your code will resume executing where it left off.

frontMatter.title: Meadow Application Sleep
frontMatter.subtitle: Reduce power consumption by putting Meadow into a sleep state.

docs.title: Events and IObservable
docs.description: Meadow has two complementary approaches to notifications when interrupts (changes) happen on inputs. The first is the classic .NET Eventing pattern, in which an event is raised on change, and the second is an IObservable pattern, which is a more powerful and flexible reactive-style approach.

frontMatter.title: Events and IObservable
frontMatter.subtitle: Understanding how to handle interrupts and notifications in Meadow.

docs.title: Meadow Hardware
docs.description: The Meadow F7 is a workhorse Wi-Fi and Bluetooth enabled System-on-Module (SoM) microcontroller-based board designed for sophisticated IoT applications and is based on the STMicroelectronics STM32F7 microcontroller (MCU) with an Espressif ESP32 coprocessor.

docs.title: Analog I/O
docs.description: In modern digital electronics, we often deal with finite states of HIGH or LOW, which represent digital 1/0, or On/Off, respectively. However, there are many sensors or other integrations that communicate not in binary, but in a range of voltages. For instance, a TMP35 analog temp sensor might output 0V when it's reading an ambient temperature of 0C, 1.6V @ 50C, and 3.3V @ 100C.

frontMatter.title: Analog I/O
frontMatter.subtitle: Reading and writing non-binary voltages via the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC), and Digital-to-Analog Converter (DAC).

docs.title: Digital IO
docs.description: Digital IO is often referred to as General Purpose, Input/Output or GPIO. GPIO ports can generally be set to be HIGH (powered at 3.3V), or LOW (grounded at 0V) which correspond to digital 1 and 0, respectively. Additionally, those values can be read, if their state is changed by an external source, when the ports are configured for input mode.

frontMatter.title: Digital IO
frontMatter.subtitle: Reading and writing digital voltage levels on the GPIO pins.

docs.title: I2C
docs.description: I2C (Inter-Integrated Circuit), pronounced, "eye-squared-sea", is a communication protocol allowing bi-directional communication between devices using only two signal wires (in addition to power and ground):

frontMatter.title: I2C
frontMatter.subtitle: Introduction to the Inter-Integrated Circuit (IIC/I2C) protocol.

docs.title: Digital Protocols
docs.description: Meadow has support for the following digital communication protocols:

frontMatter.title: Digital Protocols
frontMatter.subtitle: An overview of communication protocols for digital communications.

docs.title: SPI
docs.description: Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) is a high speed communication protocol for short distances between devices using four signal wires:

frontMatter.title: SPI
frontMatter.subtitle: Understanding the Serial Peripheral Interface.

docs.title: Serial/UART
docs.description: Standard serial, typically referred to as RS-232 or UART (Universal Asynchronous Receiver Transmitter) is a moderate-speed, reliable, old-school, digital protocol used to communicate with a single device, using two wires:

frontMatter.title: Serial/UART
frontMatter.subtitle: Serial communications over UART/RS-232.

docs.title: PWM
docs.description: Pulse-Width-Modulation is a way of controlling voltage digitally to emulate an analog signal. By turning a digital output ON and OFF very rapidly, an intermediate average output voltage can be achieved:

frontMatter.title: PWM
frontMatter.subtitle: Pulse-Width-Modulation Output

frontMatter.title: Meadow.Foundation
frontMatter.subtitle: Peripheral driver library and hardware control libraries that make IoT development plug-and-play.

docs.title: GPS/GNSS NMEA Sentence Processor Library
docs.description: The GPS/GNSS NMEA processing library is a set of classes that makes parsing and decoding NMEA Sentences from Global Positioning System (GPS)/Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receivers easy.

frontMatter.title: GPS/GNSS NMEA Sentence Processor Library
frontMatter.subtitle: NMEA sentence decoder and processing engine for GPS and GNNS systems.

docs.title: Meadow.Foundation Libraries and Frameworks
docs.description: Meadow.Foundation includes a number of libraries and frameworks to make working with embedded hardware easier, including:

frontMatter.title: Meadow.Foundation Libraries and Frameworks
frontMatter.subtitle: Libraries and frameworks that make working with embedded hardware easier.

frontMatter.title: Maple Server
frontMatter.subtitle: Using the ultra-lightweight Maple web server.

frontMatter.title: MicroGraphics Library
frontMatter.subtitle: Using the lightweight, MCU-optimized Meadow.Foundation MicroGraphics 2D drawing library with Meadow.

docs.title: MicroLayout Library
docs.description: If you're working on an IoT project with a display, then you're almost certainly wanting to show information to a user. Drawing that information using drawing primitives can be both cumbersome and non-portable. We at Wilderness Labs have released our MicroLayout library to help .NET developers easily create lightweight HMIs for their projects.

frontMatter.title: MicroLayout Library
frontMatter.subtitle: Using the lightweight, MCU-optimized Meadow.Foundation HMI UI library with Meadow.

docs.title: TextDisplayMenu Library
docs.description: The TextDisplayMenu library is an extensible framework for quickly creating hierarchical, editable menus that can display on a display that implements ITextDisplay - any graphical display via the MicroGraphics Library or supported character display and can be driven using input devices such as buttons or rotary encoders.

frontMatter.title: TextDisplayMenu Library
frontMatter.subtitle: Multiline display menu framework for quick prototyping human interfaces on connected things.

docs.title: Meadow.Foundation Peripherals Library
docs.description: The Meadow.Foundation peripherals library is an open source repository of drivers for various peripherals such as sensors, motors, displays, cameras, and other peripherals which make it easy to add hardware to your Meadow application.

frontMatter.title: Meadow.Foundation Peripherals Library
frontMatter.subtitle: Drivers for hardware peripherals such as sensors, buttons, displays, and more!

docs.title: Meadow.Foundation Unified IO Architecture
docs.description: Meadow.Foundation incorporates an architecture that was designed to extend peripheral support seamlessly across expansion peripherals such as I2C/SPI/etc. I/O expansion chips. For example, you can connect an MCP23x or 74x595 I/O expansion chip to a Meadow, and then drive a Relay via one of the pins on the expansion chip, just as if it were connected directly to the Meadow board!

frontMatter.title: Meadow.Foundation Unified IO Architecture
frontMatter.subtitle: Extending Meadow IOs seamlessly with external IO expansion peripherals via the Unified IO pattern.

docs.title: Working with Sensors
docs.description: Meadow.Foundation extends the underlying events and IObservable pattern found in Meadow.Core to sensors, providing a simple, yet powerful way to read, poll, and filter input from sensors automatically.

frontMatter.title: Working with Sensors
frontMatter.subtitle: Reading and getting updates from sensors in Meadow.Foundation.

docs.title: Automatic Restarts
docs.description: Meadow offers two systems to handle when your code doesn't behave as expected. If your application throws an unhandled exception, there is an automatic restart system for when your app doesn't recover from an error. If you have some code that might become unresponsive, there is a watchdog timer system to reset the device if some part of your code execution takes too long.

frontMatter.title: Automatic Restarts
frontMatter.subtitle: Enabling and using the Meadow systems for handling application crashes or unresponsiveness with automatic restarts and watchdog timers.

frontMatter.title: Bluetooth
frontMatter.subtitle: Meadow b5.0 BLE Draft Implementation

frontMatter.title: Cellular
frontMatter.subtitle: Connect Meadow to LTE/4G cellular signals

docs.title: Application Settings Configuration
docs.description: The app.config.yaml or app.config.json files can be used to configure application settings for logging and reboot configuration. You can also add custom developer application settings.

frontMatter.title: Application Settings Configuration
frontMatter.subtitle: Adding application settings at build-time for lifecycle, logging, or custom settings.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.description: Meadow has a robust configuration framework allowing you to adjust settings at build-time and deploy them with your app.

frontMatter.title: Configuration
frontMatter.subtitle: Controlling settings at build-time for device and app information.

next.title: SD Card use with Core-Compute module

docs.title: OS & Device Configuration
docs.description: The meadow.config.yaml file can be used to set general board and system configuration settings. This includes OS and device level settings such as device name, default network behavior, and network settings.

frontMatter.title: OS & Device Configuration
frontMatter.subtitle: Configure settings at build-time for device and network configuration.

docs.title: Wi-Fi Configuration
docs.description: The wifi.config.yaml file can be used to set the default Wi-Fi access point and the password for that access point. The wifi.config.yaml file should look similar to this:

frontMatter.title: Wi-Fi Configuration
frontMatter.subtitle: Configure Wi-Fi settings at build-time to connect Meadow to a specific access point.

docs.title: SD Card use with Core-Compute module
docs.description: The Meadow Core-Compute Development Kit includes an SD card add-on, and one can be connected to a Core-Compute module designs. You can use the SD card system for many tasks such as saving data to a removable card or providing configuration updates.

frontMatter.title: SD Card use with Core-Compute module
frontMatter.subtitle: Working with an SD card on the Meadow Core-Compute Development Kit

docs.title: File System
docs.description: Meadow.OS has full support for file and directory manipulation via System.IO API calls. In addition, the Meadow F7 board has onboard non-volatile flash storage that, while primarily used for app deployment and storage, can also be used as for persistent storage like a traditional hard drive.

frontMatter.title: File System
frontMatter.subtitle: Working with files and directories in Meadow

previous.title: SD Card use with Core-Compute module

frontMatter.title: Meadow.OS
frontMatter.subtitle: List of features and documentation of Meadow.OS

docs.title: WiFi/Bluetooth Antenna
docs.description: Both the Meadow F7 Feather development board and Core-Compute Module have an onboard ceramic chip antenna and a U.FL connector for an external antenna for the 2.4GHz WiFi and Bluetooth radio. Additionally, there is a software antenna switch for toggling between the two antenna; by default, the chip antenna is selected, and you must use the Meadow.OS device API to switch to the external antenna.

frontMatter.title: WiFi/Bluetooth Antenna
frontMatter.subtitle: Understanding and switching between the onboard and external antenna options.

docs.title: Networking
docs.description: Both the Meadow F7 Feather development board and Core-Compute Module have Wi-Fi networking via the ESP32 co-processor. The Meadow Core-Compute Module also adds optional ethernet capabilities.

frontMatter.title: Networking
frontMatter.subtitle: Network options and operation.

docs.title: Real Time Clock
docs.description: The STM32F7 is equipped with a real-time clock (RTC), which, when set, will retain the system time as long as the the board has power.

frontMatter.title: Real Time Clock
frontMatter.subtitle: Use Meadow's onboard RTC module to keep the time for logging or other use cases.

docs.title: SQLite
docs.description: SQLite Logo - A feather with the logotype "SQLIte".

frontMatter.title: SQLite
frontMatter.subtitle: Using SQLite in Meadow.OS to create and manage local databases.

docs.title: Threading
docs.description: Parallel programming in Meadow.OS is essentially the same as any other .NET enabled platform. Meadow fully supports System.Threading and System.Threading.Tasks as well as the underlying Task Parallel Library methods.

frontMatter.title: Threading
frontMatter.subtitle: Using threads, Tasks, and parallel programming in Meadow.OS.

frontMatter.title: Over-the-Air (OtA) Updates
frontMatter.subtitle: Getting setup with OtA on Meadow.Cloud

docs.description: Netduino applications are built using the .NET Microframework (v4.3), also known as (dot)NETMF. NETMF is an open source project that is further customized to run on the Netduino.

docs.description: Analog ports can operate at a range of voltages between 0 and 3.3V, which is especially useful when reading analog sensors that supply their data as a voltage reading, rather than a digital signal which is represented as binary on or off.

docs.title: MAC Addresses
docs.description: If your product has a network adapter, regardless of how it connects (WiFi, Ethernet, other), the network adapter needs to have a unique MAC address (Wikipedia link). A unique MAC address ensures that a device can have network traffic directed to it without conflicts with other devices.

docs.title: Universal Product Codes (UPCs) and International Article Numbers (EANs)
docs.description: When selling a product, most retail distributors want a unique barcode that identifies your product. The choice between a [UPC and an EAN is largely one of where you and/or your distributors are located]. Both are managed by the same organization, [GS1. Unique UPCs/EANs are needed for each product you sell, and different sizes and colors of the same product require unique UPCs/EANs. As such, the number needed can add up quickly.

frontMatter.title: Universal Product Codes (UPCs) and International Article Numbers (EANs)

docs.title: USB Vendor IDs
docs.description: If your product is accessible/connectable via USB, then you'll need to purchase a USB Vendor ID that uniquely identifies the product as yours.

docs.title: Printed Circuit Board (PCB) Fundamentals
docs.description: [Breadboards allow prototyping and developing. PCBs provide the necessary infrastructure to permanently hold electrical components together.]

docs.title: Solder Masks
docs.description: Usually, the bottom and top of a Printed Circuit Board (PCB) has a thin epoxy solder mask that covers the areas that components won't be soldered to

docs.title: Surface Finishes
docs.description: Usually, the bottom and top of a Printed Circuit Board (PCB) has a thin epoxy solder mask that covers the areas that components won't be soldered to. However, the copper areas that are exposed need also be protected and [solderability]

docs.title: Meadow Samples
docs.description: The following samples can be found in the Wilderness Labs Netduino Samples repo.

docs.title: Blinky
docs.description: Blinky is the much revered "Hello, World" app for Netduino.

docs.title: Button Interrupt Events
docs.description: This sample illustrates wiring up an event to fire when interrupts come in on an InterruptPort when wired up to a circuit that sends intermittent signals such as a button.

docs.title: Controlling a Servo Using PWM
docs.description: Servo motors (servos) are available in a wide range of sizes amd capabilities.  A servo makes it easy to add controlled motion to a project.

docs.title: Driving an LED with a PWM signal
docs.description: This sample lights up an LED with a PWM signal so that a current limiting resistor isn't needed to prevent the LED from burning out.

frontMatter.title: Driving an LED with a PWM signal

docs.title: Glitch Filtering
docs.description: The following sample illustrates configuring the glitch filter to 5 milliseconds.

frontMatter.title: LCD Display Sample
frontMatter.subtitle: Sample using the LiquidCrystal LCD library

docs.title: Onboard Button & LED
docs.description: Illustrates basic Port IO by reading the value of the Onboard Button circuit and lighting the onboard LED when the button is pressed.

docs.title: RGB LED Controlled with Potentiometer
docs.description: This sample sets the color of an RGB LED from the value read from a potentiometer. It illustrates reading an analog input and controlling PWMs with it.

docs.title: Read Date and Time from DS3234 Real Time Clock
docs.description: This application reads the date and time values from the Sparkfun DeadOn RTC Breakout Board.  This board contains the DS3234 Real Time Clock module.

frontMatter.title: Read Date and Time from DS3234 Real Time Clock

docs.title: RGB LED Blinky
docs.description: This sample illustrates a simple program to cycle an RGB LED through each of its primary colors: red, green, and blue.

docs.title: Driving an RGB LED with PWM
docs.description: This sample cycles an RGB LED through the rainbow, by looping through all possible hues in the visible color spectrum.

frontMatter.title: Driving an RGB LED with PWM

docs.title: SD Card IO
docs.description: This sample illustrates access the SD card and writing to a file using standard System.IO calls.

docs.title: Reading From a TMP102 Temperature Sensor Using I2C
docs.description: This example demonstrates how to read from a TMP102 temperature sensor using the I2C protocol.

frontMatter.title: Reading From a TMP102 Temperature Sensor Using I2C

docs.title: Writing to a TMP102 Temperature Sensor Using I2C
docs.description: This example demonstrates how to read from and write to a TMP102 temperature sensor using the I2C protocol.

frontMatter.title: Writing to a TMP102 Temperature Sensor Using I2C

docs.title: UART
docs.description: This example uses two UARTs on the Netduino and demonstrates how to send a message over one UART to the second.

docs.title: Web Request
docs.description: This sample makes a web request to http

docs.title: Web Request Multithreaded Version
docs.description: This sample makes a web request to http
